claim: Sitting close to the television can cause eyestrain.

supporting.text: Prolonged focus on a nearby screen forces the eye muscles to work harder to maintain focus, leading to eyestrain.

attacks.text: Prolonged focus on a nearby screen forces the eye muscles to work harder to maintain focus, leading to eyestrain.
Modern screens emit less harmful light and have features like blue light filters, reducing the risk of eyestrain.
Even with modern screens, prolonged close viewing can still cause temporary discomfort due to sustained accommodation effort.
Eyestrain is more commonly caused by lack of breaks during screen use rather than viewing distance alone.
Viewing distance remains a contributing factor when combined with prolonged use without breaks.
There is no conclusive scientific evidence that normal TV viewing distances cause permanent eye damage.
While permanent damage is unproven, temporary eyestrain symptoms are well-documented at close viewing distances.

supporting.text: The American Academy of Ophthalmology states that sitting too close to the TV can cause temporary eye discomfort due to excessive focusing effort.

attacks.text: The American Academy of Ophthalmology states that sitting too close to the TV can cause temporary eye discomfort due to excessive focusing effort.
Modern TVs emit less harmful radiation and have better display technology, reducing the risk of eyestrain compared to older models.
Even with modern technology, prolonged close-up viewing can still cause eye fatigue due to sustained focus at a fixed distance.
The American Academy of Ophthalmology's statement is based on older studies and may not account for recent advancements in screen technology.
The core issue of excessive focusing effort remains relevant regardless of screen technology, as it is a physiological response.

supporting.text: Blue light emitted from screens at close range can contribute to digital eye strain, as supported by optometric research.

attacks.text: Blue light emitted from screens at close range can contribute to digital eye strain, as supported by optometric research.
Most modern screens have blue light filters or low-blue-light modes that mitigate this risk significantly.
Eyestrain from screens is more strongly linked to prolonged use than proximity, as shown in ergonomic studies.
Blue light filters are often not enabled by default, and many users are unaware of them.
Even with reduced blue light, close-range viewing still forces the eyes to converge unnaturally for extended periods.
Public awareness campaigns have significantly increased adoption of blue light filters in recent years.

supporting.text: Children, in particular, may experience eyestrain from sitting too close to the TV because their developing eyes are more sensitive to prolonged near-focus tasks.

attacks.text: Children, in particular, may experience eyestrain from sitting too close to the TV because their developing eyes are more sensitive to prolonged near-focus tasks.
Modern TVs emit significantly less harmful radiation and have better display technologies, reducing the risk of eyestrain even at close distances.
There is no conclusive scientific evidence linking sitting close to the TV to permanent eyestrain in children.
Even with modern display technologies, prolonged near-focus tasks can still cause temporary discomfort and fatigue in children's eyes.
While permanent damage may not be proven, temporary eyestrain can still affect children's comfort and focus, supporting the original claim.

supporting.text: Reduced blinking while focusing on a nearby screen can lead to dry eyes, a common symptom of eyestrain.

attacks.text: Reduced blinking while focusing on a nearby screen can lead to dry eyes, a common symptom of eyestrain.
Dry eyes from reduced blinking is temporary and does not necessarily lead to long-term eyestrain.
Prolonged dry eyes can cause chronic discomfort and exacerbate existing vision problems, reinforcing the link to eyestrain.
Modern screens emit less harmful light and have features like blue light filters, reducing the risk of eyestrain regardless of distance.
Even with reduced harmful emissions, prolonged close-up screen use still strains eye muscles due to sustained focus at a fixed distance.

supporting.text: The contrast and brightness of modern screens at close range can cause visual fatigue over extended viewing periods.

attacks.text: The contrast and brightness of modern screens at close range can cause visual fatigue over extended viewing periods.
Modern screens often include features like blue light filters and adaptive brightness to reduce eyestrain.
Blue light filters and adaptive brightness are not universally effective and may not fully prevent visual fatigue.
Eyestrain from screens is more related to prolonged use rather than proximity to the screen.
Proximity to the screen can exacerbate eyestrain when combined with prolonged use, especially in poorly lit environments.
